title: Investigating Relational Rule Learning
text:
This project conducted over two semesters investigates relational rule learning by exploring how the degree of understanding of a relational rule affects participants’ mastery rates across tasks of varying difficulty, whether prior training on a specific relational rule (rule matching) improves task accuracy, and whether interleaved pretraining—mixing different relational rules during training—enhances task performance. This project was my first experience with multilevel modeling, which I learned through hands-on lab work rather than formal coursework.
Collaborators: Julia Conti and Paulo Carvalho

title: Gender Stereotype Threats and Academic Performance
text:
This project investigates how gender stereotype threats affect academic outcomes using meta-analysis tehcniques in R. Results showed that both affirmative and non-affirmative interventions improved performance compared to no intervention, despite limited data for subgroup analysis.
Collaborators: Amor Ai, Sisley Yang, Frank Janicke, Eesha Nagpal, and Camille Chandler

title: Predicting Flight Delays in Pittsburgh
text:
Using real data from 2022 and 2023, this project predicts 2024 flight delays from Pittsburgh International Airport. We trained a random forest classifier and achieved 78% prediction accuracy.
Collaborator: Emily Jiang

title: Statistical Insights into Medical Incident Records
text:
This project analyzed medical incident patterns, focusing on needs levels and time-to-report across types and time. We used statistical tests like Fisher’s exact, time series, survival analysis, and Kruskal-Wallis. I specifically handled medication error analysis. Here you can find the presentation and my detailed report for our nonprofit partner, Mainstay Life Services, which supports individuals with intellectual disabilities and autism in residential or home settings.
Collaborators: Emily Zhu, Sophia Mou, Alva He, Derek Gao, and Edward Brownhill

title: Helen Peng
text:
I’m a senior at Carnegie Mellon University, majoring in Statistics with a concentration in Psychology. I’m interested in using data to address real-world challenges, especially in public health and education. Currently, I am a member of OAK Lab where I’m investigating relational rule learning.

Outside of academics, my hobbies are simple: reading and watching dramas. I’m drawn to stories that reveal something deeper about how people think, connect, and navigate the world. If you’re curious, I’ve listed a few favorites under the Bookshelf tab.

title: Bookshelf
text:
Favorite Quotes





Widget by Goodreads



Favorite Books


                           



Favorite Comics
I’ve read a ton of X-Men over the years. Beyond the powers and fight scenes, what sticks with me is how it reflects real-world struggles faced by marginalized communities. I’ve always loved the way Magneto and Professor X parallel Malcolm X and Martin Luther King Jr. — that contrast in ideology makes the story hit deeper. I used to have a whole screenshot stash of the funniest X-Men moments, but it got lost somewhere along the way. So here’s to starting fresh and rebuilding the archive (well eventually… under construction)



imgs <- list.files("comics", pattern = "\\.(png|jpg)$", full.names = TRUE)
htmltools::HTML(paste(sprintf('<img src="%s" style="height: 200px; margin-right: 10px;">', imgs), collapse = ""))

title: Exploring Mental Health Among COVID-19 Graduates
text: This project investigates how graduating during different phases of the COVID-19 pandemic (peak vs. decline) affects depression and hope levels among students. Using publicly available data, I applied PCA and logistic regression models to analyze mental health outcomes. Results indicate that students who graduated during the pandemic’s decline in 2021 experienced greater psychological distress compared to those graduating at its peak in 2020.

title: Impact of Incentives on Visual Search Performance
text:
This project explores the effects of incentives on visual search performance. The task was developed using Gorilla, and data were analyzed in Jamovi. Findings indicate that while incentives may affect search efficiency, their overall impact on performance was modest and not statistically significant.

Collaborators: Cami Streuly, Shirley Du, and Cole Kaforey

title: Gender Stereotype Threats and Heading-Recall Task
text:
This project investigates the impact of gender stereotype threat on memory performance through a heading recall task. Conducted in Gorilla, with data cleaned in Excel and analyzed in Jamovi, the results revealed non-significant but suggestive trends in how stereotype threat may influence memory processing.
Collaborators: Cami Streuly, Shirley Du, and Cole Kaforey
